stem: A 48-year-old client with a history of kidney stones presents with 'excruciating' flank pain. Based on the documentation in the Renal Imaging & Output Log, what is the most likely cause of the client's acute kidney injury (AKI)?

options.text: Post-renal AKI due to ureteral obstruction

rationale.correct: This is **post-renal AKI (a1)**. The imaging shows a large 9mm stone obstructing the ureter, leading to **hydronephrosis** (backup of urine into the kidney). This pressure prevents the kidney from filtering blood, causing the creatinine to rise. Because it is a physical blockage 'past' the kidney, it is categorized as post-renal.
clinicalPearls: Hydronephrosis = Urine backup. If it's bilateral or in a patient with one kidney, it causes rapid AKI.
Treatment involves removing the 'plumbing' problem (stent, lithotripsy, or surgery).
Colicky pain radiating to the groin is a classic sign of a stone moving down the ureter.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the creatinine rise is always 'internal' kidney damage.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always look for the 'mechanical' cause. If you see stones, prostate enlargement, or tumors in the urinary tract, it's a 'pipe' problem (post-renal).

exhibits.title: Renal Labs
exhibits.content:
Serum Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL (Baseline 0.8).
BUN: 46 mg/dL.
Urine Output: 50 mL in 4 hours (oliguria).

exhibits.title: KUB X-Ray & Ultrasound
exhibits.content: Impression: 9mm calculus (stone) at the right ureterovesical junction (UVJ). Significant **hydronephrosis** of the right kidney. Left kidney appears normal.

exhibits.title: Nurses Notes
exhibits.content: Current: Client is pacing the room; reports 10/10 colicky pain radiating to the groin. No nausea or vomiting. Blood pressure 164/98 (pain-related hypertension).
